title: Family spends 6 months turning house into Halloween attraction
text:
Halloween producer Jason Blum on resurrecting a horror classic and why people love being scared

A family have spent half a year and considerable funds transforming their handsome Queensland home into a nightmarish scene from an iconic horror film.

The parents from the Gold Coast, who are going by the pseudonyms Mr and Mrs Strappleberry, spent six months and the cost of a “jet ski” transforming their home, on Pandora Crescent in Pacific Pines on the Gold Coast, according to the Daily Mail.

The family, who are transforming their home for Halloween for the second year in a row, said after using a smoke machine and fake spider webs last year, they noticed more kids and families in the neighbourhood trick or treating.

“It was wonderful to see excited kids out having fun, so we decided we could do more,” Mr Strappleberry said.

This year’s elaborate design, partly inspired by Stephen King’s IT, has been dubbed Panic on Pandora by the family. They’ve created their own Facebook page, and told news.com.au today they have officially gone “viral”, after making the news, and receiving more than 1500 likes social media.

The home features spooky weatherboarding, a large spider on the exterior (named Barry) and a haunting figure of Georgie, the child character from the Stephen King novel, among numerous other scary features.

Mr Strappleberry told the Daily Mail that Halloween is a “24/7” thing for the family and the ideas are constantly flowing.

“Planning takes maybe six months to narrow down what we wanted to create this year,” he said.

He didn’t reveal the exact cost of the project but said, “It was either a jet ski for me or a Halloween event for everyone.”

The family’s goal is to create an attraction for kids and families.
description: A family have spent half a year and considerable funds transforming their handsome Queensland home into a nightmarish scene from an iconic horror film.
